climbs.name: Three Guys and Heather
climbs.fa: Bill Robins, John Giebelhauson, Will Kelly, Heather Kelley. Nov. 1997

content.description: Maybe with a cleaning this might be a descent route, until then do yourself a favor and avoid this adventure. I pulled toaster size blocks off and held them so as not to flatten my belayer. Much scree came down on the upper half. So I guess I am adding this in case you were thinking of trying it. The lower half has some cool wild climbing, but the upper part is choss.
content.location: next  crack system right of Ten Minutes

content.description:
This is a pretty good climb, stiff for the grade. The harder part is the lower seam of a crack.

If you are not well versed in thin cracks, you may want to TR this, pretty pumpy placing gear near crux start.
content.protection: Single rack, tips to #4 camalot. Bring a #5 or #6 cam to protect the wide but easier section to anchors. This route ends at an independent chain anchor 10' below and to the right of "Preying Mantel" BEWARE OF LOOSE ROCK
content.location: Starts just right of Preying Mantel. For both of these climbs it helps to start the belay on the ledges above the trail, but one could lead up from the trail as well.

content.description: Oddball low angle vantage mixed climb that is harder than it looks. Stems and face holds (crux) up to a roof with anchor chains above. Supposedly a popular route back in the day.
content.location: Bolted line directly left of Preying Mantle and right of "Pounded Again", which is the 5.11b mixed line with 4 pitons.
Short bolted climb left of the Chossmaster.

content.description: This route follows the obvious set of 10 or 11 closely spaced and right-leaning bolts in the center of the tilted pillars. Most of the challenging climbing comes in the first half and consists of cryptic mantles and wide stances. You can either start from the ground near the trail or from the top of the short broken pillars at the start of the route.
content.protection: 10 bolts. Optional gear (2" cam) if starting from the ground. Anchor chains.

content.description: This is a variation start to Ten minutes of warmth. Three bolts lead to a small ledge that then leads into a 15ft hand crack that ends below a roof. Cut left at the roof into the wide crack finish on ten minutes of warmth. End at anchors for ten minutes of warmth.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a single rack from bd #1-5. A #6 wide cam could also be used in the upper wide crack but is not really needed. Two #4s would likely work instead of bringing a #5.
content.location: The open book with three bolts to the right of ten minutes of warmth.

content.description:
Jam or lieback a 15' perfect thin hands left facing corner crack to the top of a semi-detached column. Do a fun move to step right and gain another 15' splitter thin hands crack to the top.

Not amazing nor difficult, but a fun respite from facehold-heavy trad climbs at the this wall.. the pro is bomber!

Final 15' of low 4th class to the chains is littered with loose choss, just like Chapstick- be careful!
content.protection: Gear to #2, doubles of 0.75. 304 Stainless steel chain anchor installed 3/21/2021
content.location: A few columns up the gully from Chapstick; look for the short LFC with a perfect crack.

content.description: left most route on the wall. some loose rock. protects well with mostly finger sized pieces.
content.protection: bolted anchor hidden to the left of the boulder, or walk off.

climbs.name: Another Notch in My Lipstick Case

content.description:
guidebook: "Climb hand crack in a rich facing corner moving left onto a ledge.  Next follow a thin crack past a bulge.  After the bulge, crack widens and eases as your ascend."

A VERY fun beginner trad route.  I found the beginning better if done as a set of stemming moves.  And then moving into the crack.

There is a little bit of loose rock on the route so use caution.
content.protection:
I found placements for doubles in bd 1s, 2s and down through the sizes.  So a full rack with doubles (only carrying 2's or smaller should do you fine).  I brought nuts didn't end up finding placements for them.

Also due to the cliff at the base of the climb, never a bad idea to throw some pro and protect your belayer.
content.location: Just above the trampled bush at the base of the tiled pillars
